lines: P R O C E E D I N G S
CHAIRMAN:  We'll explain that in a couple of minutes.
Then put into a three dimensional grid, if you will.
100 metres by 100 metres, so it's about the size of
four of these ballrooms put together and it's about 2
metres tall, so it's about my height I guess, just to
get a sense and our model has I think eight and a half
so you can imagine they're quite big, but it's all
digital, right?  It's a digital representation on
a computer.
Just to make a quick point here is so this is from
our example and because we know this and we have the
data available, this shows a well and the point I want
to make clear is that a model starts out empty, so
most of the cells in a model when we're looking at
a field like D1-D3 field start out temporary and it's
only after we understand -- only cells that are known
are where the wells are.
A. So in our case, of the 8.4 million cells only about
3,700 of those cells actually intersect the well data.
So all the rest you know basically 99.99 per cent of
the cells we have to populate and we do that using our
expertise.
SIR BERNARD RIX:  And using state-of-the-art software to
build the geocellular model.
CHAIRMAN:  What's the reference to 8 million cells?
Where is that?
A. Sorry, it's right there, yeah.  Just to get a sense
that most of the model has to be built, you know, by
the geologist, geophysicist and all of these millions
of cells have to be assigned a value, porosity, net to
gross, water saturation, permeability, all of those
have to be assigned and we do that using our expertise
and algorithms, but also --
CHAIRMAN:  Isn't that done by the digital equipment?
A. It's done by the digital equipment guided by us.
Guided by the operator of it.  So we tell the digital
equipment how to do the process.  Yes.  But it does
run.  We give it the parameters to work with.
CHAIRMAN:  I might have misunderstood it, but I thought
the digital equipment produces the images that portray
what is there and then:
"The skill of the human being is break it down and
to interpret what is there and whether it has any gas
or oil relevance."
A. Yeah, that's the case with seismic data it is
projected to us and we interpret seismic data and this
is a type of seismic data that's probably been spoken
already RTI that's very important to this field.
And so this is the actual seismic data and it's
been tuned to really highlight gas pay.  So this is
a well and these are gas pay sands in the well and
this is the seismic data that's calibrated to that.
MR DAYAL:  Yes, so there is data that's presented to us
and we interpret, but then we take that data and we
along with algorithms we extrapolate the model, you
know, into space.
Where we have data like this, we have very high
confidence in our modelling, you know, where we have
less confidence when we're away from control like the
seismic control, if that makes sense.
CHAIRMAN:  Did this technology grow out of the search for
oil or does it go hand in hand with oil and gas?
A. It's oil and gas hand in hand.  This is seismic
technology has been I think -- well, I think it's been
around since the 1940s in the offshore environment
like where we are here, I think, you know, seismic
like the type we have here probably started in the
1980s and then again log data it keeps improving in
quality over years on year it gets better technology,
better resolution, et cetera.
CHAIRMAN:  The search for submarines in the last war
shown in war movies was an early form of seismic
search, was it?
A. Sonar would be another good example, right.
Sonar is going to pick up a submarine, but it
could also penetrate and see stuff down below.  You
can do sonar and actually see features, you know,
below the seabed, that certainly a good analogy.
MR SALVE:  So I mentioned a couple of things.  I'm going
to try to move along here quickly, but what I want to
say from here is at the time of the AIDP
pre-production there were uncertainties and we had
estimates of net pay that the contractor was relying
on, GCAs and also Schlumberger and what they gave
Reliance at the time of the whole thing it wasn't what
they hoped for, but it's the way it is.  The AIDP was
what we believe to be higher values than are currently
understood now post-production.
So that the key question is and again it really
was the thin beds that I talked about where the
difficult ones, the blocky sands are easy to evaluate.
Everyone gets those right.  Those aren't in question.
The difficult bit are is how much and how extensive
are the thin beds and how much they will contribute
gas to the overall field.
I also talked about models, so these are very
schematic, but if you can imagine this is
a cross-section through one of the channels in the
D1-D3 fields and in the AIDP the model was what we
call unconfined.  So it meant that we had these
channels and the thin beds, the levees and the
overbanks could extend a great distances away.
What is turned out post-production with the
knowledge of post-production -- and Phil will talk
about that in a second -- is that our understanding is
now unconfined or excuse me confined, so this these
channels now are encased in a canyon and that these
thin beds that were thought to extend a great distance
away now appear to be basically stopped and are really
in this canyon and don't extend much beyond it.
So that's the crux and I just want to point out
that pre-production is a type of the AIDP and these
are volumetric metrics.  We didn't have production
data yet and Mr Spellman in a second here will explain
to you the importance of the production data.
MR SPELLMAN:  Thank you, Phil.
Phil described seismic data covers the entire
block, but it's not detailed resolution.  You then
drill wells and get logs and that gives you more
specific detail you get core out of a smaller set of
wells because you don't core everywhere.
The next piece of informations that a very, very
important piece of information is what we call I'll
refer to as performance data which is going to be
production and pressure data.  So as the field
produces, you keep track of the pressure initially and
then watch that as the field produces.
We liken that to letting the reservoir tell you
what size it is by listening to it.  There was
a couple of suggestions of analogues of gasfield
balloon or decompressing aeroplane.
We thought this tank of compressed gas was
a better analogue than what we had before when it
changes shape, changes size and a reservoir doesn't
do that.
Then the decompressing aeroplane we that's not how
the gas was produced so whatever is a compressed gas
table and it's showing the original pressure we have
a valve to simulate the 18 wells -- phase 1 wells.  So
we're going to turn on this valve.  We're going to let
that gas produce, we're going to measure the pressure
from the pressure gauge and we're going to keep
talking about how much production is coming out of it
and plot that up on a simple pressure versus
cumulative production plot.
That's what's shown there as the field is moving.
You see the second valve show us.  That's the phase 2
drilling that was contemplated in the AIDP and if you
continue down to monitoring that pressure you project
that data it's going to project to the gas in place
estimate and that would project to receiving 6 TCF
before the end of the year.
This is an illustration only we've got multiple
P/Z plots for the visit well that is we can go into
detail.  This is just an illustration to show that.
That was the understanding of how this reservoir
should have performed.  But we don't know it.  We
don't know how big the tank is.  We have the estimate
from the volumetric.  Phil has described it, but we're
going to go ahead and put this reservoir back on
production.
So we got phase is wells drilled, the original
pressure is the same, but we see that as the
production continues, that the reservoir pressure is
dropping faster.  And that was noted by the parties,
that it was dropping faster than expected and it's
really dropping faster than what it would have if you
had a 16.3 TCF reservoir.
You look at that up the actual data and it's
telling you that you're got about 4.5 TCF of gas and
that's about the volume that was estimated, you know,
in the RFDP timeframe, so a couple of years after
production started.
So that's what caused the geoscientists and the
engineers to go to this field and find out where did
the gas go?  That's what happened to everyone.
That's the two:
"Of the big components are the confined unconfined
nature of it.  He also mentioned the laminated sands."
CHAIRMAN:  Don't understand that confined.  What was the
confined name "zero" it.
MR SPELLMAN:  The deposition pre-AIDP was that it was
confined to the whole and could extend large
distances.
A. No, you're telling.  Confined model means that if you
don't have this contained system, if you don't have
these boundaries that are confining the reservoirs,
then these thin beds can extend a long way and they
could and would contribute as the field was being
produced they would contribute back to these main
channels where the bulk of the wells would be located
in the confined system.
Again, basically, the same picture, but we have
this whole thing again, so these are actually these
things, these channels and levees overbanks are
trapped in the canyon and again outside as it turns
out after more investigation by the contractor, turned
out to be not containing the thin beds as expected.
So that's the differences is unconfined, able to
go all the way from the channel system, and confined
most of the gas resources are right to go somewhere
the channels are -- if that helps.
CHAIRMAN:  We normally have morning tea break and I don't
want to interrupt your presentation.
How long is now left in your oral presentation of
these slides?  Please don't feel obliged to rush it.
I want to understand this.
WITNESS:  I'd say it's probably, what, 15 minutes.
Yeah, probably a few more minutes.
CHAIRMAN:  Is it acceptable to continue for 15 minutes?
MR KOHLI:  May I just point out one thing.  Many of the
questions that I have are relating to these slides.
So this presentation is actually quite helpful because
those are the questions I had to ask to make sure that
everything is fully explained.
If the gentlemen here take a few more minutes to
actually explain it properly, I won't be minding that
at all.
CHAIRMAN:  Yes, well, I feel much the same as you,
Mr Kohli.
And I was thinking during this presentation that
it might for any future arbitrations of this kind, be
beneficial to have, if necessary, a couple of experts,
because they may not disagree, but if this had been
given at the very beginning to the subcontractor --
I'm not criticising anybody -- it would, I think, have
been helpful.
So let us press on, and you take the time that is
necessary.
A. Thank you, sir.
So the production performance, you know, that we
saw just illustrated by that schematic of a tank with
compressed gas being produced from it, indicates that
smaller volumes were actually in the field until just
described parts of the component is due to the
confined/unconfined interpretations.
The other part, as Phil mentioned, in going
through the log analysis the net pay pre-production
and post-production was significantly reduced and
that's because the contributions from the thin bed
sands did not come into play once the production data
was available.
So there was adjustments made to the
confined/unconfined system and also to the net pay
calculations.
Yeah.
1   Q. I just briefly talk about this.  This is a graph of
the gas in place estimates original gas in place
estimates, so this is the 2P estimates through the
whole time of the experience in January 2009, you have
production data that's now available pre-production
and all the estimates through time is additional wells
were drilled which is the blue line showing the well
dropped out numbers were going up and then after
production of the numbers have been taken down to the
levels which you see over there on the graph.
That's a judgment, a summary of that.  It's a wide
range of estimates.  Post-production there's a pretty
tight range of estimates from multiple consultants.
2   Q. So natural processes --
CHAIRMAN:  Can I ask a question that arises out of
Prof Cameron's report.  He denies that he is engaging
in just retrospective examination and being wise of
events.  He says once it's after events and this has
really fallen, you have to go back and ask what you
failed to do earlier in the life of the exploration.
So at some stage in your presentation, I'd like
you to explain why it wasn't possible to get the
warning signals that required not only that Reliance
would inform the government exactly what was
happening, which is a question, but that it would have
alerted those who are scientists looking at this, who
are professional people doing their job, of really
examining what steps had to be taken to put this in
reverse given that the signals were coming that it was
really a very disappointing well, a very disappointing
source?
A. Right.
CHAIRMAN:  That I think is really at the heart -- core of
this, of the conflict between the parties.  So what --
A. Yes, we don't directly address that head on in this
presentation.  What we're trying to show is the data
that was available at the various points in time, the
tools that were available to analyse that data and how
that data was used and we stopped short of addressing
the question you just brought --
CHAIRMAN:  We'll come to that in due course, no doubt.
A. Yes, sir.
CHAIRMAN:  But with the help of anything you have to say
about the exploratory process that will help us to
understand that question at the end of the testimony?
A. Yes, sir.
3   Q. So this is a quick analogue here just to, you know,
modelling is -- excuse me, modelling is difficult
sometimes, modelling and this is an example of
forecasting storm tracks and I draw this analogue to
the difficulty especially prior to the getting
production data to estimating the gas in the D1-D3
field.  So this is an example from the Gulf of Mexico.
This is a storm from 2022 called Tropical Storm Ian
that turned into a hurricane and all of these tracks,
these are models, you know, multiple realisations if
you will, of how this storm could track three
days out.
So you can see that the predictions from competent
meteorologists scientists using modern software there
was a wide range of uncertainty and that's the nature
of natural processes, is there's a wide range of
uncertainty.  So how did this turn out?  Well, again
predictions got better as you got closer to landfall,
but the prediction was at the edge.  It was maybe the
far edge of one of the predictions.
So the landfall was actually just outside this
range of uncertainty.
So here are the estimates from leading experts in
the D1-D3 fields pre-production and it also had a wide
range of uncertainty.  But you see, you know, coming
from all the way from the low case, if you will, the
best, the proved case of D&M, all the way to the 3P
case, if you will, of Gaffney Cline.
You can see a range of expert estimates of what
the OGIP is in the D1-D3 fields.
But landfall, if you will:
"Turned up to be herein a the edge of the range of
uncertainty and that just happens.  We see it in our
business."
That you can do your best efforts to estimate gas
in field, but sometimes it's just, you know, whatever
circumstances more complexity, more a model that turns
it not correct leads you to find out that it's
actually much less than was predicted and that's what
happened to the contractor here is that.
CHAIRMAN:  We will take a short break now.
(Short break)
CHAIRMAN:  Did you take remedial steps or cut our losses
much earlier than we did?
I'm sorry to keep taking you back to the core of
the problem that is before us, but anything you can
say on that -- I mean, this is an enormous variation,
from a layman's point of view, in what the experts are
saying.
Maybe that's relevant to the solution of the
ultimate problem, but is that an unusual configuration
that you're now showing us in the range of
uncertainty?  Is that unusual in your business to have
such variations from a well that appeared to be or
source that appeared to be very promising at first?
The "glorious days", as Reliance called those first
days, the "glorious days of exploration".
A. I guess in our experience, it happens.
It's not real frequent, but if we look at what we
see at the beginning, looking at the other side of the
storm, landfall all those models were created by
meteorologists that knew what they were doing, they
were using the best technology at the time and the
answer landed within the range of what was estimated
and it was at the edge of the range and that's the
situation we have here.
CHAIRMAN:  I would have thought that in this technology,
in this context, there would have been much more
commonality in the estimates, in fact, it's mildly
shocking to see that GCA estimate 27.196 and landfall,
it's to a layperson, it's seems that there's big
variation?
A. Yeah --
CHAIRMAN:  The question is: ought that to have rung
bells?  Which is what I think Prof Cameron is telling
us.  It ought to have rung bells.  It ought to have
alerted Reliance to the fact that this was not going
to be the "glorious days".  This was a bummer.
A. We think there were several things that led to this.
We talked about log analysis.
You know, the estimating pay if the thin beds, so
this was in early 2000s, you know, so these types of
reservoirs were still being understood, you know, now
they're much better understood.
You know, now threat does not have to be like
this.  In various countries at this time, there were
fewer and the technology to understand those thin beds
that we talked about was evolving, frankly, and it
appears that almost like a pendulum swinging too far
that Schlumberger, who is an adviser to the
contractor, you know, predicted, you know, quite a bit
of pay in those thin beds and we think that because
they went from a place where they couldn't see pay in
thin beds at all, say so years earlier.
It's almost as if the pendulum swung, so they
started to make a dispute and these how you get to
16 TCF instead of 4, you know, it's those two factors.
You know, you have to weigh both of those to
understand and understand that this was still evolving
technologies, especially on the log analysis side in
that timeframe.
It wasn't fully mature technology, because we
hadn't seen if the industry we hadn't seen those types
of reservoirs frequently in this type of environment
and it took a while to understand them.
So that's my explanation, sir, as to how you could
end up at that much difference.
CHAIRMAN:  Yes.  I interrupted you.  You press on with
your final description.
A. Thank you, sir.
So once the data started come in indicating that
the field was not as big as the AIDP, they had to make
a turn and change how they evaluated developed the
field, because and they did some pretty creative thing
in our opinion, in managing the field that was much,
much smaller.
As we talked about they design at world class data
well production programme, once they got into the
operations, any did some things that were pretty
creative with managing pipelines and operating the
filed for the D6 next to the D1-D3 using that
commonality of the facilities and so we can cover that
in more detail in our second report.
But in the interests of time, we'll try to move
through.
CHAIRMAN:  Yes, please go ahead.
A. So we took a look at some of the claims that there was
mismanagement going on in the field.
CHAIRMAN:  Is this a convenient point to break?  Because
I think --
A. It can be, yeah.
CHAIRMAN:  I think you've got us to the point where
you --
A. We're making a turn.
CHAIRMAN:  It's now 12 o'clock, so if we take a cup of
tea for quarter of an hour and then come back at about
just after quarter past 12.
Please don't talk to others about your evidence
and it will be more powerful if we have your
unblemished, unaffected opinions.
A. Yes, sir.
CHAIRMAN:  The tribunal will adjourn now until 20
past 12.
SIR BERNARD RIX:  You certainly should not be talking to
lawyers during your evidence.  You're in a form of
purdah.
WITNESS:  Understood.
(Short break)
MR KOHLI:  You didn't know history matching?
A. Make sure there is a reason for going to this side of
the well formation information.
SIR BERNARD RIX:  I'm not hearing you terribly well.  Can
you move the microphone as close as possible.
A. Sorry.  Is that better?
SIR BERNARD RIX:  The closer the better.
A. Okay.  Thank you.
Sorry, could you repeat your question?
SIR BERNARD RIX:  I think you answered it, that you
didn't go back to the beginning and then there may
have been another question.
MS BAJAJ:  No, he didn't answer the question.
MR KOHLI:  No, sir.  They didn't answer the question.
Mr Spellman said they want to make sure that I'm
answering your question here.  My question was -- just
one moment.
Yeah.  My question was that you picked up the
field as it was performing as a moving car:
"You didn't really check out from where it had
started and what could have possibly gone wrong."
A. Our analysis went back to the beginning to the
original gas in place and then recoverable estimating
recoverable volumes.
4   Q. You were supposed to answer the question whether the
contractor has been following good international
petroleum industry practices during its operations;
right?
A. Yeah.
SIR BERNARD RIX:  Well, this is before.  It's in 2010.
MR KOHLI:  This is in 2010, sir, but I'm just saying
that --
SIR BERNARD RIX:  The question had not by asked by King
& Spalding.
MR KOHLI:  That is true.  I'm just asking about whether
in 2014, when those questions were asked to you, did
you, at that time, go and check whether the field had
been operating well since the beginning or did you
not?  Because if you were to certify that they are
following GIPIP, you would have checked it out right
from the start.  Or did you check out whether they're
following GIPIP after 2014?
A. It would have been after 2024.  We looked at the
current operations after 2014.
5   Q. So when you answer the question that the operator or
the contractor has been following GIPIP, am I to
understand that you mean that they've been following
GIPIP after 2014?
A. No.
6   Q. It's what you said.
A. Well, let me restate that, then, because I must have
misspoke.
The engagement with King & Spalding was in 2014.
That included the three questions.  One of those
questions was operations related.
Operations folks went back to, I guess,
a combination of things.  To look at the development
plan as it was executed and then also to look into
various other things in the post-2014 timeframe which
are the reports that you referred to.
7   Q. So am I to understand and please correct me, am I to
understand, you went back and looked at the AIDP?
A. We did not look at the AIDP.  We had our operations
folks can look at how wells were drilled, they can
look at completions and comment on that without
knowing what the AIDP had in it.
8   Q. So how would you certify the operations as following
GIPIP and then without looking at the development plan
to say:
"Whether it's adhering to the development plan."
A. Your operations engineer can look at well completion
reports to see how the wells were drilled.
(The hearing adjourned until 9.30 am on the following day)
